snippet: Mitt Romney aggressively pressed President Obama on the economy, jobs and health care in a debate that avoided the one-liners that sometimes emerge from presidential face-offs.
abstract: Pres Obama and Mitt Romney appear in the first televised presidential debate of the election cycle, with each arguing that his policies would improve the lives of the middle class; Romney forcefully engages Obama throughout the 90-minute event as they clash over the economy, jobs and health care, but neither candidate delivers a knockout blow; Romney succeeds in showing that he could project equal stature to the president, perhaps offering a lift to his campaign that could reorder a close race.

byline.original: By JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG

lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney aggressively pressed President Obama on the economy, jobs and health care in a debate that avoided the one-liners that sometimes emerge from presidential face-offs.

headline.seo: Obama and Romney Hold First Debate
headline.main: Obama and Romney, in First Debate, Spar Over Fixing the Economy
headline.print_headline: Obama and Romney, in First Debate, Spar Over Fixing the Economy
headline.sub: Candidates Quarrel on Deficit and Taxes in First Meeting
